title: Greetings and Introductions
learningObjectives: Ask and answer simple questions about yourself
Use polite expressions in everyday situations

sections.title: Saying Hello
sections.content: Greetings are the first words we say when we meet someone. In English, we have different ways to say hello. The most common greeting is 'Hello' or 'Hi'. We can also say 'Good morning', 'Good afternoon', or 'Good evening' depending on the time of day.

sections.title: Common Greetings
sections.content:
Here are the most common greetings:

• Hello / Hi - Use anytime
• Good morning - Before 12:00 PM
• Good afternoon - From 12:00 PM to 6:00 PM
• Good evening - After 6:00 PM
• How are you? - A friendly question after greeting

When someone asks 'How are you?', you can answer: 'I'm fine, thank you' or 'I'm good, thanks'.

sections.title: Introducing Yourself
sections.content:
When you meet someone new, you introduce yourself. Here's how:

• My name is [your name]
• I'm [your name]
• Nice to meet you
• Pleased to meet you

Example: 'Hello, my name is Maria. Nice to meet you.'

You can also say where you're from: 'I'm from Spain' or 'I'm Spanish'.

sections.title: Conversation Examples
sections.content:
Example 1: FIRST MEETING - 'Hello! My name is Sarah. Nice to meet you.'

Example 2: ASKING HOW SOMEONE IS - 'Good morning! How are you today?'

Example 3: INTRODUCING YOURSELF - 'Hi! I'm Carlos. I'm from Mexico.'

Example 4: POLITE GREETING - 'Good evening! It's a pleasure to meet you.'

sections.title: Polite Expressions
sections.content:
Being polite is important in English. Here are essential polite words:

• Please - When you ask for something
• Thank you / Thanks - When someone helps you
• You're welcome - Response to 'thank you'
• Excuse me - To get attention or apologize
• Sorry - To apologize

Example: 'Excuse me, can you help me, please?' 'Yes, of course!' 'Thank you!' 'You're welcome!'

sections.title: Key Takeaways
sections.content:
Remember:
• Use 'Hello' or 'Hi' to greet people
• Say 'My name is...' to introduce yourself
• Ask 'How are you?' to be friendly
• Always use 'please' and 'thank you'
• Say 'Nice to meet you' when meeting someone new

Practice these greetings every day and you'll feel more confident speaking English!

keyVocabulary.definition: A greeting used when meeting someone
A word used when leaving or ending a conversation
To see and talk to someone for the first time
A polite word used when asking for something

grammarPoints.explanation: Both are correct for introductions. 'My name is' is slightly more formal.
examples: My name is Maria Garcia. (full name)
commonMistakes: Saying 'I am name is John' - Wrong! Say 'My name is John'

grammarPoints.explanation: Use this question to ask someone's name. 'What's' is short for 'What is'.
examples: What's your name? - My name is Carlos.
What is your name? - I'm Sarah.
May I ask your name? - I'm David. (more polite)
commonMistakes: Saying 'How is your name?' - Wrong! Say 'What's your name?'
Answering with just the name without 'My name is' or 'I'm'
